Dr. K,

Dr. Summers & Dr. Yellen both have excellent qualifications but, in truth, Dr. Summers has negative baggage in that he seems to be the principal that advised the President to pivot to the "Fix the Debt" policy position at the most critical time in the faltering recovery. The Keynesian approach was called for & no one took to the pulpit to educate the American public. In short, we let Mr. Peterson et al along with the undetected error of Ken Rogoff & Carmen Reinhart have the fiscal policy field with no opposition.

When we started laying government workers off in the middle of this recovery, I thought the WH had lost its mind. Then after the U.K. did its double dip recession in response to their austerity cuts & we persisted in increasing taxes on the American workers and agreeing to the sequester, I was convinced that we had checked our frontal lobes at the door.

For President Obama to erase that regrettable & unfortunate history he will have to reject the Summer's idea of cutting spending to decrease the annual deficit & go whole hog for creating good paying jobs for the remainder of his term. Step one is to make a statement on the appointment of Dr. Yellen & reject the ideas that were adopted by his Administration in the Summer and Fall of 2011.

Now is the time to be assertive & insist on repeal of the sequester & restoration of a tax cut for the middle class & do something bold like launch the a National Superconducting Maglev Network initiative.

I'm afraid I botched the statements by trying to state them briefly.

Def.1 Let a Colm Sequence be a sequence {a(i) i = 1, 2, ...} where i a(i) a(i)+a(j) <= a(j+1)
(I used "ordered" because if one writes down the pairwise sums in the natural way then for an ordered Colm Sequence the sums are ordered.)

Clearly a Fibonacci Sequence is an ordered Colm Sequence.

Conjecture 1 should have read that among all ordered Colm Sequences (of length n) the Fibonacci sequence has the smallest a(n). I think this is hard.

Conjecture 2 should have read that every Colm sequence is dominated by an ordered Colm sequence.

Conjecture 2 is trivially true. If {a(i)} is a Calm Sequence let b(i) = 10^a(i) then {b(i)} is ordered and {a(i)} is dominated by {b(i)}

OMG - I've noticed this too & so have friends & colleagues: we hardly ever see anyone age 55+ on the subway or high-traffic business areas of the city.

I notice when I ride the subway at rush hours - in various parts of the city - I'm often the only person age 55+ in that subway car - or even in the station!

I do see older people riding the buses - but more often during non-rush hours, and they don't seem dressed for work.

Is it that very few of us are still in the workforce in NY? Is it that my peers can no longer manage subway stairs or crowded cars & platforms? But there always used to be older people riding the subway - including very elderly people.

I do see many older people in my largely residential neighborhood who use the local UPS store, Post Offices, & Starbucks for their home-based businesses. Is that it? We've been forced out of full-time employment prematurely - & we're making do with home-based work?

"Abducted by aliens" starts to seem plausible. Beam me up, Scotty!

Earlier today, I stopped to check e-mails on a bench behind the Museum of Natural History. On the bench next to mine sat an older man finishing a meatball hero. He wore a jacket w/ a badge that read, "Volunteer." When he'd finished, I asked if he was a docent at the Museum & he replied that he was. He told me he had work as a research scientist at Columbia University for 30 years, and although rewarded w/ an excellent pension, missed coming in to City. He then asked me what I was doing out in the middle of the day, I told him I was on my way to see a show at the New-York Historical Society.

He asked about my work—I told him I was a Brand Consultant, but I haven't worked since April. He thought it was terrible and began to speak about the real state of unemployment, other than that reported by the White House & parroted by mainstream media.

I told him that up until a few years ago, if I walked from 5th Avenue and 59th Street to the Village, I ran into a dozen clients, colleagues, friends, but today I can walk for days and not see anyone. I am 57 and most of my peers seem to have been abducted by aliens, or slipped out of the city in the middle of the night. Those w/ jobs do the work of two or three people w/out complaint for fear of losing their jobs.

People in media believe "content" is the future—Mr. Blattman was lucky to become first Mr. Winerip's, then Mr. Brokaw's. By turning himself into a commodity, he found work. It will not be that easy for most of us.

500 resumes are a lot, but without reading Christen's book, I can guess by the "parachute" name is that it promotes in-person "networking".

Save yourself $20 by not buying or reading her book; a 20-year old edition is about the same and you can backfill with internet articles on job search techniques.
Also, remember there are 5 "actions' for each situation presented -- there isn't just one.

For 25+ yrs I have told my clients to have plan B,C, and D as you just cannot predict when and if your current career derails. Downturns, age, life events, and change happens...especially technology.

Hiring managers and recruiters find candidates differently with the advent of Linkedin and social media. Now, a job search is mostly online until you walk in the door to interview. As one search consultant put it, "you need a big digital footprint" as he checks to see, "the digital exhaust you leave behind".

The founder of Linkedin urged in his book The Startup of You to build a career and find jobs by networking.

What does all this mean?
-your online presence is more important than the resume.
-lots of Linkedin connections means more opportunities come your way not 100's but 1000's
-that who you know and get to know matters
-in an era of job scarcity and high job competition your resume must be walked into the company rather
-mass applications don't work

It means that our careers are like paper not oil: sustainable and recycleable,
Plan on having your career derail over and over.
Plan on having salary fluctuations that increase with career velocity and maturation. Plan on morphing into a new career and industry....again.
Plan on pursuing your dream this time around maybe?

In "Morale Victory", an episode of M*A*S*H (season 8, episode 19), music-loving surgeon Major Charles Winchester performs a brilliant operation that leaves his patient only with damage to his right hand.

What he does not know is that the patient is a concert pianist, who emerges from the surgery angry. Winchester requests copies of various piano scores, including that Ravel Concerto, from Seoul.

Winchester presents the sheet music to his patient, telling him of Paul Wittgenstein, who lost his right hand during World War I yet continued performing by commissioning works for piano using only the left hand.

When the injured pianist rejects it because he doesn't want to be a "freak", Winchester corrects him:

"Don't you see? Your hand may be stilled, but your gift cannot be silenced if you refuse to let it be… The gift does not lie in your hands. I have hands, David. Hands that can make a scalpel sing. More than anything in my life I wanted to play, but I do not have the gift. I can play the notes, but I cannot make the music. You have performed Liszt, Rachmaninoff, Chopin. Even if you never do so again, you've already known a joy that I will never know as long as I live. Because the true gift is in your head and in your heart and in your soul. Now you can shut it off forever, or you can find new ways to share your gift with the world – through the baton, the classroom, or the pen. As to these works, they're for you, because you and the piano will always be as one."

I hear you..and have been in your shoes.  Having said that, it's hard to have sympathy for a guy who worked in the student loan industry -- an industry that is at the forefront of destroying the "American Dream."

It is so very easy to blame others...whether you've been through this economic debacle and have soldiered on with your job and finances intact, or whether, like Mr. Blattman, you've lost so much. The fact is, that for numerous well educated, previously highly paid middle aged citizens, their lives have been forever altered by the last 5 years. With neither the time remaining to learn new skills and become experienced in their use, or to put enough money aside to feel financially secure again, I can assure you that we who have weathered this badly have felt more heartbreak than anyone can possibly know.

The money is the least of it in the end. I can live without new clothes, or fancy meals. A new car, vacations or any one of the small ways that I remind myself I used to live and must now do without. I put on my best face every morning and psych myself up to go out and make the best of the meager job I now have. My spirit, always my best and strongest skill has taken quite a beating. I lament to myself often and to others less so about what a loser I am that this has happened to me. The first time I went to the grocery store I was in tears looking at everyone with full baskets...when I had $10 to spend for the week...I remembered when I could go and spend freely.

Trust me, many of us who are in this predicament did most things right...and we are making the best of it...but a little compassion goes a very long way.

Wow! Touching story. I am 55 and I was laid off as a public school teacher when the recession hit in 2008. I have been able create an online business editing the English of scientific papers written by non-native speaker authors and teaching English to people in other countries. I pieced it together myself. I love the this work, because I am still growing as a teacher and editor. However it hasn't matched my former income yet, but I also have a flexible schedule and free time to watch our son and help with other household chores. It has been a struggle and a blow to my self-esteem to lose my job, but stories like this make me feel like it's not about me failing, but something that devastated a whole generation. Mr. Blattman makes a good point: it's less about the money your earn, but more important to get up everyday, give it your all, and at the end of the day feel good because you were useful. I have that in my work, yet until I make what I was formerly making, I guess I am still haunted by self doubt. Yet, this story eases my grief. Thank you NYTImes. Good luck Mr. Blattman. Without knowing you, I understand the anguish you must have gone through. Hang in there and don't give up the struggle!
